I’m going to love her till the cows come home
 I bet I’ll love her more

The true origin of this phrase is unknown but it’s first appearance in print was the January 1829 Times magazine:

If the Duke will but do what he unquestionably can do, and propose a Catholic Bill with securities, he may be Minister, as they say in Scotland “until the cows come home.

We can only guess the phrase comes from Scotland! The statement is certainly attributed to the sluggish movement of the animals.

Come on, on my way
 ’Cause I’m-a going to see my baby today

This song has a high energy cruising beat, what makes it really stand out, is how it shifts back and forth between an upbeat major key and ominous minor key. This really reflects how much he desires to see his “baby”, quite reminiscent of songs like: The Box Tops “The Letter”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BQaUs5J2wdI

Come on if you please
 I’ve got no time for trivialities
 I’ve got a girl who’s waiting home for me tonight

The Beatles must have been so busy during these days. Playing shows, recording an album, filming a movie! They still managed to find time to attend multiple parties and celebrations. These lyrics are ripe with frustration towards their overzealous work schedule.



Their work ethic definitely matches their polished sound.

Yet another Beatles song inspired by Motown. In particular Wilson Pickett.

That’s me again, another Wilson Pickett, Motown sound, a four-in-the-bar cowbell song.

John was inspired to use the same cowbell in “You Can’t Do That”
